ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of techniques and formalisms in statistical mechanics as they relate to chemistry. Learned how to numerically model and compute observables with programming projects and written homeworks.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very clear and complete lecture notes from the professor. The textbook was difficult to read though and maybe too advanced for an introduction to the subject.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For students intending to study chemistry at the graduate level, I would recommend they take the course. However, if students have never been exposed to classical thermodynamics (e.g. free energies, ensembles, Maxwell relations, Gibbs construction for phase transitions, gas equations of state) and some basic constructions in statistical mechanics (e.g. partition functions, Boltzmann distribution), this course is too advanced.
